stories.title: Twitter expands ‘Safety Mode’ feature to half of all Canadian accounts

stories.text:
I love the side and meta discussions and comments that happen on HN, but sometimes I just want to read the next comment that responds to the actual content of the article.
Would be lovely to be able to collapse a sub-thread (the way you can in many IDEs).
Would other users find this helpful as well?
stories.title: Ask HN: Would you like for HN to have a collapse thread feature?
Link Between Vitamin D and Covid-19 Reaffirmed in 'Striking' New Findings
The world of PostgreSQL wire compatibility
Erik Prince Helped Raise Money for Conservative Spy Venture
The tangled history of mRNA vaccines
Alan Turing, Trees, and the Wonder of Life

stories.text:
This tweet (https://twitter.com/gossipbabies/status/1487161069143576576) resonated with me and I wonder how common my experience is. Working at smallish web software companies over the past few years I have observed a trend toward increasingly many specialized SaaS products for stuff that might previously have been handled by (for example) emails, spreadsheets and documents.

Are you seeing this as well? What kinds of systemic issues do you think might arise from this sort of change? Have you, or your organizations, evolved any strategies for balancing operational complexity and information siloing against the perceived benefits of this kind of SaaS specialization?
stories.title: Ask HN: Strategies for managing the proliferation of office SaaS products?
